questions.prompt: In BG 7.1, what principle does Krishna ask Arjuna to do?
choices: Leave battlefield through independent material engagement processes
Hear about knowledge and entirely surrender to Krishna
Study scriptures alone through independent material speculation
Perform rituals through worldly philosophical speculation only
questions.feedback: Asaktena (without attachment), mat-parah (devoted to Me)-practicing yoga hearing about Me-will know entirely. The trap: knowledge accumulation without devotional context. Why this matters: The false path is academic Krishna-study-learning philosophy/theology without mat-parah (devotional orientation), producing theoretical knowledge not transformative realization. Real understanding: Complete knowledge (asamshayam samagram) requires asaktena (detached from material) plus mat-parah (devoted to Krishna)-devotional relationship providing framework for genuine understanding. Hearing about Krishna (mayi shrinvat) in devotional consciousness enables complete realization. Therefore approach Krishna-knowledge devotionally-not as subject for study but as Person for relationship, transforming information-gathering into devotional realization.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.2, what false path does Srila Prabhupada warn against regarding spiritual knowledge?
choices: Pursuing intellectual understanding without practical realization through devotional service engagement
Reading too many books instead of focusing on single scripture study alone
Seeking knowledge from spiritual teachers rather than discovering independently through speculation
Studying philosophy before establishing firm foundation in ritual worship practices
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that theoretical knowledge alone is insufficient. One must combine jnana (knowledge) with vijnana (realized understanding) through practice. The trap is accumulating information without transformation. Why this matters: Modern seekers confuse intellectual grasp with actual realization. The false path is studying endlessly without applying knowledge in devotional practice.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.3, what distinction does Srila Prabhupada make between jnana and vijnana?
choices: Jnana is theoretical knowledge; vijnana is realized practical understanding
Jnana comes from books; vijnana comes from direct guru instruction
Jnana is intellectual understanding; vijnana is emotional devotional feeling
Jnana means material knowledge; vijnana means transcendental scriptural study
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that jnana means theoretical knowledge of the spirit soul's nature. Vijnana means practical realization of spiritual truth through devotional practice. The trap: collecting information without transformation. Why this matters: The false path is academic study without applying Krishna consciousness in life. Real spiritual advancement requires both theoretical understanding and practical realization.

questions.prompt: What does BG 7.4 teach about Krishna's energies?
choices: Krishna has no power through speculative material processes
My energy divides into eight aspects manifesting all beings
Everything is one through speculative material processes only
Only one primary energy exists through material speculation
questions.feedback: Eight-fold apara prakrti (lower nature)-earth/water/fire/air/ether/mind/intelligence/false-ego. The trap: matter as ultimate reality. Why this matters: The false path is materialism-treating eight elements as fundamental reality, missing they constitute apara (lower/inferior) prakrti subordinate to para (higher) spiritual nature. Real understanding: Material elements are mama maya (My energy)-Krishna's external potency creating/maintaining material cosmos. Apara means inferior not in value but in consciousness-level-matter is unconscious energy serving conscious spirit. Therefore recognize matter's subordinate status-Krishna's energy not independent reality, tools for spirit's education not ultimate ontology, inverting materialist hierarchy placing matter above spirit.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.5, what false conception does Srila Prabhupada warn against about the living entity?
choices: That living entities are simply combinations of material elements only
That souls gradually evolve from matter through biological processes over time
That consciousness emerges from complex chemical reactions in the brain
That individual souls will eventually merge into one impersonal existence
questions.feedback: Beyond apara (lower material) prakrti is para (higher spiritual) prakrti-jiva-bhutah (living entities) sustaining jagat (world). The trap: monistic oneness. Why this matters: The false path is undifferentiated Brahman-declaring living entities identical with Supreme, missing para-prakrti (superior nature) distinction from apara-prakrti (inferior nature). Real understanding: Living entities constitute para-prakrti (superior spiritual nature) distinct from apara-prakrti (eight material elements)-higher than matter but subordinate to Supreme. Neither material (apara) nor Supreme but intermediate category-simultaneously one and different. Therefore understand acintya-bhedabheda-living entities ontologically distinct from both matter and Supreme, occupying intermediate position as Supreme's eternal marginal energy.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.6, what is the origin of all beings?
choices: All beings are eternal through independent material processes
I am the source of everything that exists
Matter created itself through independent material processes
Beings created randomly through independent material processes
questions.feedback: All beings' source (yoni) I am-and pralaya (dissolution) also. The trap: deistic absent-creator. Why this matters: The false path is clockmaker-God-creates universe then abandons to independent function, missing Krishna's ongoing involvement as both origin (utpatti) and dissolution (pralaya). Real understanding: Jagat (world) originates from Me and dissolves into Me-continuous relationship not one-time creation. Yoni (womb/source) metaphor indicates ongoing sustenance not just initial production. This establishes panentheism not deism-universe exists within Krishna's energy under His control. Therefore relate to active involved Supreme-not distant historical creator but present sustainer-dissolver, recognizing creation's ongoing dependence on Krishna's continuous energetic manifestation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.7, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada identify about perceiving the Absolute?
choices: Thinking the Absolute must be impersonal because personal form suggests material limitation
Believing that God's form must conform to our material imagination and expectations
Assuming the Absolute can be fully understood through logical reasoning and philosophy
Concluding that all paths lead to same destination regardless of actual understanding
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns against the impersonalist error - thinking that personality implies material limitation. This is the mayavadi trap: projecting material defects onto the spiritual realm. Why this matters: The false path is rejecting Krishna's personal form while claiming to be advanced. Real knowledge accepts the Absolute Truth as simultaneously personal and unlimited.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.8, what principle does Krishna identify as His living energy?
choices: Matter alone through worldly material speculation
The sound vibration OM representing spiritual energy
Time alone through worldly material speculation
Space alone through worldly material speculation
questions.feedback: I am rasa (taste) in water, prabha (light) in sun/moon, pranava (om) in Vedas, shabda (sound) in ether, paurusham (ability) in men. The trap: pantheistic identity-confusion. Why this matters: The false path is 'I am water, I am sun'-confusing Krishna's presence as primary quality with object itself, producing monistic reduction. Real understanding: Krishna is essential quality enabling manifestation-rasa making water tasteful, prabha making sun luminous, pranava making Vedas authoritative. Not the things themselves but their essence. Recognizing Krishna in phenomena without confusing Him with phenomena. Therefore practice discriminative perception-see Krishna as essential quality enabling all manifestations without reducing Him to manifestations, maintaining distinction-in-identity preventing pantheistic collapse.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.9, what are examples of Krishna being the original of all?
choices: Krishna is present primarily only in formal temple worship and rituals
I am fragrance in earth, heat in fire, life in all living beings
Examples of Krishna's presence cannot be given through speculative material processes
Only minimal qualities come from Krishna through independent material speculation
questions.feedback: Punyo gandhah (pure fragrance) in earth, tejas (brilliance) in fire, jivana (life) in all beings, tapas (austerity) in ascetics-I am. The trap: identifying Supreme with particular manifestations. Why this matters: The false path is limiting Krishna to sublime experiences-only special fragrances/brilliant fires/extraordinary lives, missing He's present in all instances of category as essence. Real understanding: Universal presence through essential qualities-punyo gandhah (pure fragrance) indicates fragrances' common essence not particular smell. Every fragrance manifests Krishna's presence-ordinary and extraordinary. This democratizes divine perception. Therefore develop universal vision-recognize Krishna in all instances of essential qualities not just impressive manifestations, seeing Supreme's presence in common phenomena not just extraordinary experiences, preventing spiritual elitism.

questions.prompt: What does BG 7.10 teach about Krishna's powers?
choices: Krishna has no power through speculative material processes
Force of energy is essence, everything rests on my potency
Power is only temporary through speculative material processes
Only one primary thing has power in material existence
questions.feedback: Bijam (seed) of all beings, buddhi (intelligence) of intelligent, tejas (prowess) of powerful-I am. The trap: glorifying particular excellence. Why this matters: The false path is personality-cult-glorifying specific intelligent/powerful persons while ignoring quality's universal source, producing false hero-worship. Real understanding: Krishna is buddhi buddhimatam (intelligence of intelligent), tejas tejasvinam (prowess of powerful)-not praising individual but recognizing source. Every intelligence/power manifests Krishna's presence-great and small. Individual excellence should direct attention upward to source not terminating in person. Therefore practice source-attribution-see impressive qualities as Krishna's manifestations, praising Him through them not replacing Him with them, preventing creature-worship through recognizing Creator behind all creature-excellence.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.11, how does Krishna manifest in the world?
choices: Only in temples through formal worship and ritualistic ceremonies alone
As strength of strong devoid of passion and dharmic desire
In nature alone through independent material processes without any purpose
Through intellectual speculation and philosophical debate exclusively without devotion
questions.feedback: Balam (strength) free from kama-raga (desire-attachment) I am-and kama (desire) not contrary to dharma. The trap: absolute desire-condemnation. Why this matters: The false path is universal desire-rejection-treating all kama (desire) as spiritual obstacle, missing dharma-congruent desire as Krishna's manifestation. Real understanding: Strength without kama-raga (lust-attachment) is Krishna; and kama aviruddha dharma (desire not contrary to dharma)-regulated desire compatible with Krishna. Not all desire is lust-dharmic desire for progeny/service/protection represents Krishna. Therefore discriminate desire-types-reject adharmic kama (sense-indulgence) while honoring dharmic kama (duty-motivated desire), avoiding both libertine acceptance of all desires and ascetic rejection of all desires through dharma-based discrimination.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.12, what is Krishna's relationship to the modes of material nature?
choices: Krishna is controlled by the three modes like all other beings
All modes emanate from Krishna, but He remains transcendent to them
The modes exist independently without any connection to Krishna
Krishna identifies Himself completely with the mode of goodness
questions.feedback: Sattva/rajas/tamas bhavas (states)-all from Me eva (alone), but not I in them, they in Me. The trap: pantheistic immanence without transcendence. Why this matters: The false path is limiting Krishna to material manifestations-'God is in everything' without recognizing He transcends everything, reducing Supreme to material categories. Real understanding: Modes originate mattah (from Me) but na aham teshu (not I in them)-Krishna source of gunas but transcends them. Asymmetrical relationship-modes depend on Krishna, Krishna independent of modes. This preserves both immanence (modes from Krishna) and transcendence (Krishna beyond modes). Therefore recognize Krishna's simultaneous immanence-transcendence-present in creation as source yet untouched by creation's limitations, neither pantheistic reduction nor deistic distance.

questions.prompt: What does BG 7.13 teach about those attached to material desires?
choices: They progress spiritually through independent material processes
They worship demigods seeking temporary material rewards
Everyone gains equally through independent material processes
Material desire is good through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Tribhih guna-mayaih (made of three gunas) bhavais (states)-entire world mohita (bewildered) doesn't know eternal Me beyond gunas. The trap: guna-identification as self. Why this matters: The false path is identifying with mode-based personality-'I am intellectual/passionate/lazy'-missing these are temporary guna-conditions not eternal identity. Real understanding: Whole world mohita (bewildered) by three guna-mayaih bhavaih (states made of gunas)-identifies with temporary mode-combination. Doesn't recognize Krishna param (beyond) gunas as actual self's source. Gunas are clothing not wearer. Therefore transcend guna-identity-recognize thoughts/feelings/behaviors as mode-expressions not self-nature, seeing past guna-covering to eternal spiritual identity as Krishna's servant beyond material psychological types.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.14, why does Srila Prabhupada warn that maya is insurmountable by material effort?
choices: Because maya actively prevents all spiritual progress through constant material engagement
Because only surrender to Krishna provides the power to overcome maya's illusion
Because maya requires many lifetimes of gradual purification before transcendence
Because maya is ultimately more powerful than God's grace and divine mercy
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that maya is daivi (divine) and cannot be overcome by personal effort. Only by surrendering to Krishna does one cross over. The psychological trap is thinking self-improvement alone can achieve liberation. Why this matters: The false path is attempting spiritual advancement through willpower without devotion. Real transcendence requires grace through surrender.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.15, what types of fools are mentioned?
choices: Only the ignorant through independent material processes
Those who know not my transcendental divine nature
All people are wise through independent material processes
Knowledge brings problems through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Na mam dushkritinah (evildoers not to Me) prapadyante (surrender)-four types: mudha (foolish), naradhama (lowest), mayayapahrita-jnanah (knowledge stolen by maya), asuram (demonic). The trap: universal divine acceptance regardless of character. Why this matters: The false path is sentimental universalism-'everyone worships same God'-missing that character-defects prevent Krishna-surrender. Real understanding: Four obstacles-mudhah (foolish materialists), naradhama (degraded misusing human life), mayayapahrta-jnanah (pseudo-intellectual with distorted knowledge), asuricam bhavam ashritah (those accepting demoniac nature)-all avoid surrendering to Krishna. Character matters-certain corruptions prevent spiritual receptivity. Therefore cultivate receptive character-overcoming foolishness/degradation/distorted-knowledge/demoniac-mentality enabling Krishna-surrender, recognizing spiritual path requires character-development not just intellectual assent.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.16, what warning does Srila Prabhupada give about approaching God with material desires?
choices: That any approach to God, even with desires, is completely worthless and condemned
That distressed and desiring devotees are pious but must eventually seek pure love
That only those approaching without any motivation whatsoever can be accepted
That material desires automatically disqualify one from any spiritual progress completely
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada explains that approaching Krishna even with material desires is pious, but the highest platform is seeking Krishna without expectation. The trap is either rejecting conditional devotees or remaining stuck in material motivation. Why this matters: The false path is thinking impure motivation prevents spiritual life. Real progress allows gradual purification from material desires to pure love.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.17, among those who approach Krishna, who is dearest to Him?
choices: The distressed through worldly philosophical speculation
The wise serving me with single-pointed devotion
The wealthy through worldly philosophical speculation
The powerful through worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: All four devotee-types are udarah (magnanimous), but jnani atmaiva (My very self) me matam (I consider)-constantly engaged. The trap: path-equality dogma. Why this matters: The false path is refusing hierarchical distinction-treating all devotional approaches as equally advanced, missing qualitative development from material to pure motivation. Real understanding: All four types noble but jnani represents highest-unmotivated pure love after transcending distress/desire/curiosity. Atmaiva me (My very self)-complete identification through love. Not devaluing lower stages but acknowledging progression. Therefore aspire upward-honor all devotional starting-points while recognizing goal as pure unmotivated love, validating gradual purification from mixed to pure bhakti through stages.

questions.prompt: In BG 7.18-19, who are truly wise according to Krishna?
choices: The learned scholars who understand through speculative material processes
After many births, wise know me as everything that is
Material scholars are wisest who study through speculative processes
No one is truly wise who relies on speculative material processes
questions.feedback: All four devotee-types (arta/artharthi/jijnasu/jnani) are udara (noble), but jnani is atmaiva (My very self)-most dear. The trap: equal-value relativism among devotees. Why this matters: The false path is treating all devotional motivations equally-missing progressive hierarchy from material distress-relief through enlightenment-seeking to pure love. Real understanding: All four types noble-distressed, materially desirous, curious, wise-but jnani in pure love is atmaiva Me iti (My very self). Qualitative progression-begin with material motives, gradually purify to unmotivated devotion. Jnani prioritized not from favoritism but from love-quality. Therefore aim for jnana-bhakti-appreciate all devotional beginning-points while aspiring toward unmotivated pure love, recognizing spiritual path's developmental nature from mixed to pure motivation.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.19, what false conception does Srila Prabhupada address about spiritual advancement?
choices: That anyone can achieve full realization quickly through weekend meditation retreats
That after many births of seeking, the wise person recognizes Krishna as everything
That spiritual knowledge develops automatically without sustained practice or study
That material advancement and wealth indicate spiritual progress and divine favor
questions.feedback: After bahuni janmani (many births), jnani (wise one) knowing vasudevah sarvam (Vasudeva is all) surrenders-such mahatma su-durlabhah (very rare). The trap: instant enlightenment or common attainment. Why this matters: The false path is either expecting immediate realization or assuming many achieve it-missing that genuine Krishna-surrender after complete understanding is su-durlabhah (extremely rare). Real understanding: Bahuni janmani (many births) required for full realization-not quick achievement but gradual development over multiple lifetimes. Vasudevah sarvam iti (Vasudeva is everything)-complete understanding enabling total surrender. Such mahatma very rare-acknowledges path's difficulty preventing false claims or discouragement. Therefore maintain realistic expectations-genuine realization rare and gradual, inspiring sustained effort without illusions of easy achievement or false success-declarations.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.21, what happens when Krishna grants desires to other deities' worshippers?
choices: Krishna denies them completely through speculative material processes only
I grant desires, but they eventually return to material world
They achieve complete liberation through speculative material processes entirely
They prosper forever eternally through speculative material processes constantly
questions.feedback: Kamais tais taih (by various desires) hrita-jnanah (stolen knowledge)-worship anya-devatah (other gods) adopting various practices by svabhava (own nature). The trap: polytheistic tolerance. Why this matters: The false path is religious relativism-'all paths equally valid'-missing that desire-driven demigod-worship indicates hrita-jnana (stolen knowledge) not spiritual advancement. Real understanding: Those whose jnana (knowledge) hrita (stolen) by various kamais (desires) worship other deities-not respecting diversity but diagnosing distortion. Desire-motivation reveals knowledge-absence despite religious forms. Therefore discriminate motivation-devotion to Krishna versus demigods differs in consciousness-quality not just ritual-forms, kamya-karma (desire-motivated worship) indicating spiritual immaturity regardless of deity worshiped.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.20-23, what psychological trap does Srila Prabhupada identify about demigod worship?
choices: That demigods are completely imaginary and worshiping them produces no results
That worship of demigods brings temporary rewards but distracts from ultimate goal
That demigod worship is equally valuable as Krishna worship for spiritual liberation
That demigods are more accessible than Krishna and therefore better for beginners
questions.feedback: Srila Prabhupada warns that those of small intelligence worship demigods for temporary material benefits, missing the supreme goal. The trap is being satisfied with lesser attainments. Why this matters: The false path is seeking material solutions from demigods while neglecting Krishna. Real intelligence directs worship to the Supreme Source who can grant both material and spiritual perfection.

questions.prompt: How do BG 7.4-5 and 7.14 work together to explain why surrendering to Krishna is the only way to transcend maya?
choices: Material energy is weak, so anyone can overcome it through willpower and determination
Maya (material energy) is Krishna's divine potency and insurmountable except by surrendering to Him
The living entities are products of material energy and have no independent existence
Material and spiritual energies are equal, so one can choose either path freely
questions.feedback: This synthesis reveals the paradox of spiritual life: maya (Krishna's inferior energy) is divine and insurmountable by material effort, yet Krishna's superior energy (the living entities) can transcend it through surrender. The living entity is superior to matter but inferior to Krishna. Why this matters: The false path is attempting self-improvement without grace. The psychological trap is pride in personal effort. Real transcendence recognizes that only by connecting to the Supreme through surrender can the soul overcome the divine illusion. This explains why Chapter 6's yoga requires devotion, not just technique.

questions.prompt: According to BG 7.25, why do foolish people mistake Krishna for a mortal?
choices: It is obvious Krishna is mortal being
They cannot understand my transcendental divine nature
Everyone knows Krishna's nature through material processes
This does not happen through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Antavat tu phalam (limited fruit) tesham (of them)-worship demigods leads to their worlds, but My devotees come to Me. The trap: result-equivalence among religions. Why this matters: The false path is outcome-agnosticism-assuming all worship yields same destination, missing that deity determines destination-quality. Real understanding: Demigod-worshipers reach deva-lokas (temporary heavenly planets) with antavat phalam (limited results)-returns to material cycle. Krishna's devotees reach Him-permanent liberation. Therefore recognize destination-difference-not all worship equally efficacious, deity-choice determines outcome-quality, Krishna-worship alone transcending material rebirth-cycle while demigod-worship yielding temporary elevation within material existence.

questions.prompt: How does the progression from distressed/desiring devotees (BG 7.16) to wise devotees (7.17-19) illustrate the purification of motivation in spiritual life?
choices: All devotees must start with pure love; those with material desires are disqualified completely
Material motivation gradually purifies through devotional contact until one recognizes Krishna as everything
The four types of devotees remain forever separate with no possibility of advancement
Only philosophical study without devotional practice can transform material into spiritual understanding
questions.feedback: Avyaktam (unmanifest) vyaktim (manifest) apanna manyante (think attained)-mudha (foolish) don't know param (supreme) avyayam (imperishable) bhava (nature). The trap: avatara as ordinary incarnation. Why this matters: The false path is reducing Krishna's appearance to material birth-soul entering body, subject to birth-death like ordinary beings, missing transcendental nature. Real understanding: Mudhah (foolish) think avyaktam (unmanifest/impersonal) vyaktim apannam (has become manifest/personal)-that formless becomes formed through material manifestation. Don't understand param avyayam bhavam (supreme imperishable nature)-Krishna eternally possesses transcendental form not acquired through material birth. Therefore recognize Krishna's eternal form-not that formless becomes formed but that transcendental form appears/disappears in material vision, preserving divinity against Mayavada reduction.

questions.prompt: In the purport to BG 7.25, why does Srila Prabhupada explain that Krishna is not manifest to everyone?
choices: Because Krishna randomly chooses favorites and conceals Himself from all others arbitrarily
Because Krishna is covered by yoga-maya and foolish people cannot understand Him properly
Because Krishna lacks the power to reveal Himself to materialistic people lacking devotion
Because people must achieve specific realization levels through effort before seeing Krishna
questions.feedback: Naham prakashash (I am not revealed) to sarvasya (everyone)-covered by yoga-maya. Mudha (foolish) nabhijanati (don't know) ajam (unborn) avyayam (imperishable) Me. The trap: universal divine accessibility. Why this matters: The false path is automatic Krishna-realization-assuming sincere interest suffices for darshana, missing yoga-maya covering preventing casual vision. Real understanding: Krishna not prakashash (revealed) to everyone-covered by yoga-maya (internal potency). Mudha (foolish) material-oriented persons don't recognize ajam avyayam (unborn imperishable)-requires spiritual qualification. This explains why most don't perceive Krishna despite presence. Therefore cultivate qualification-Krishna reveals proportional to purification, not automatically visible but disclosed to prepared consciousness, requiring devotional practice removing yoga-maya covering.
